repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Biodiversity Conservation and
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for Cameroon - Biodiversity
            Conservation and Management project were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that conservation of biodiversity
            is not the concern of only scientists, government officials,
            international NGOs, civil society or local population; it
            requires contributions and cooperation from all of these
            with the government retaining the initiative and overall
            leadership. Government ministries in charge of forestry and
            wildlife have "public authority"
            ("r�lien") duties, which are to enforce forestry
            and hunting laws and regulations. Local populations must
            further be allowed to seek cooperation with other potential
            stakeholders (private operators e.g. logging companies,
            safari hunters and international NGOs). In a country as
            diverse in all respects as Cameroon, decentralization is key
            for the Program to be effective at local level. It is
            unrealistic to expect concrete achievement in the domain of
            biodiversity conservation without explicit consent and
            active participation of local populations. To achieve this,
            it is necessary to empower these to as great an extent as
            possible, and to give official recognition to this
            empowerment. Sustainable sources of funding must be secured
            in order to strengthen the local organizations, provide
            adequate compensation for the sacrifices made by local
            populations for biodiversity conservation, and to sustain
            community-based development. Effective GIS on all aspects of
            natural resource management and biodiversity conservation
            are key to providing information, which must be made
            available transparently to all stakeholders in order to help
            in joint decision-making on very sensitive issues. The
            program initially invested heavily in studies, surveys and
            consultancies, however without building real capacity in the
            field or for Ministere de l'Environnement et des For�
            (MINEF). The Programme de Conservation et de Gestion de la
            Biodiversit�u Cameron (PCGBC) was implemented through a
            "program approach". The Unit�echnique Op�tionnelle
            ("UTO") approach was very effective in urgently
            addressing a situation within a zone that required a direct
            coordination and approach and helped unite stakeholders.

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Biodiversity Conservation and
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Biodiversity
            Conservation and Management Project is to consolidate and
            upgrade the management of protected areas in Cameroon by: 1)
            providing support to the Government in its efforts to
            conserve and manage its biological resources; 2) promoting
            involvement of rural populations in biodiversity
            conservation; and 3) encouraging sustainable utilization of
            renewable natural resources and promoting sustainable and
            environmentally compatible development in regions
            surrounding the protected areas. The project will enhance
            biodiversity conservation and management at six priority
            project sites. These areas include the coastal
            Guinea-Congolean refugium and the western highlands. The
            project will underwrite studies necessary to identify
            priority protection and produce management plans for
            critical core areas integrated within a network of
            multiple-use management zones. The project will also finance
            conservation of savanna ecosystems including implementation
            of a recovery plan for the endangered black rhinoceros. The
            project will strengthen key institutions concerned with
            biodiversity research and provide resources, training and
            technical assistance to improve their ability to fulfill
            their mandate. The project will also strengthen the Studies
            and Planning Services (SPS) of the Department of Wildlife
            and protected areas (DWPA).

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Conservation de la biodiversite
            au Cameroun

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this environmental
            analysis are to: 1) identify the environmental and
            socioeconomic impacts of the project; and 2) recommend ways
            to alleviate the negative impacts and protect
            Cameroon's biodiversity.  This analysis outlines the
            positive impacts that will result from the project both in
            terms of biodiversity conservation and in terms of improved
            living conditions.  The paper also gives a detailed analysis
            of the negative impacts on the environment by focusing on
            three different regions: Boumba Bek, Loubeke, and Campo.
            Based on these analysis, the paper offers recommendations
            for both project design and project implementation.
